Review title: A brutal Edward Norton makes you sit up through this American history
Review_body: It is a powerhouse performance by Edward Norton that drives this compelling drama to a whole new height. Mr. Norton plays “Derek” a Nazi skinhead ex-convict who tries to prevent his younger brother “Danny”, played astutely by Edward Furlong, from going down the same path. The movie is narrated by both these protagonists as plots and sub-plots get unfolded smoothly. The plot is relatively simple but it’s the natural ease with which all actors play their parts that ignites the story. Mr.Norton is absolutely convincing as the angry young man, furious at his social system and in the process gets caught up in his own ideologies.Scowling and scoffing at anyone who is non-white, Mr. Norton delivers a performance worthy of his Oscar nomination; a perfect foil to the timid “Narrator” of Fight club. The scene in which he grins at his brother as he gets arrested and then the shocking realization as he is dragged away from his family is a gem.The other actors including Edward Furlong have played their parts extremely well. The characters have been sketched extremely well and reflect the contemporary American society. Edward Furlong as “Danny” who worships his brother reminds a little of the spoiled child in T2-Judgement Day. Derek’s mom, the mentor “Mr.Sweeny” and even Mr. Norton’s friend in prison, all are memorable characters that do stick in your mind. The film does have flaws. I found the movie a little short for its social undertone, but that’s acceptable since the director did not want to delve too much into Derek’s past. But his transition from the brutal skinhead to the redeemed prisoner is not as developed as one might expect. This is where the movie could have gained more intensity. It is not really clear why Mr. Norton lands in trouble. As a result, this sequence alone comes out half baked; a very crucial under-development to the storyline. Typical of its genre, the redeemed man is not let off the hook that easily. We know life is going to come hard on Mr. Norton. The shattering climax was expected but not surrealistic. "History X" suffers from falling into stereotypes so characteristic of it's genre. Nevertheless, it is a hard hitting movie on racism and depicts the underlying tensions in an American neighborhood with absolute sincerity. However it’s the charismatic Mr. Norton who elevates this 'just another tale of redemption' into a cinematic masterpiece. The bottom line;racism is a cancer. You try hard to wipe it out; it reappears in some other way more lethal than ever before. Watch American History X for its greatness in its social message; Watch it for “Derek”. As a cinema goer you will be enthralled; as a human being you will be concerned.

What has to happen to transform a committed member of a skin head gang into a person willing to die to free his family from his mistakes? In American History X (1998), rated R for graphic brutal violence including rape, pervasive language, strong sexuality, and nudity, the story focuses on Derek Vinyard as he struggles to overcome the hate taught to him by his father and friends. The movie has a powerful message that steers clear of becoming a clichéd story about everybody getting along. It is a very dark movie that deals with very powerful themes such as racism and hate and also the ability to overcome these feelings. While the movie can at times feel rushed it is overall a very good movie that shows the transformation of one man and his family.In this movie all of the characters look the part of skinheads and racists, with shaved heads and clothing bearing the pictures and slogans of hate. Derek has gone one step further than this; he has covered himself in tattoos of swastikas, SS lightning bolts, and other symbols of hate. One of the most powerful scenes in this movie comes when Derek stands in front of the mirror after being released from prison and covers up the large swastika tattoo over his heart with his hand. Also when Derek is released from prison he also begins to let his hair grow out again, no longer keeping his head shaved, showing in one more way that he has changed and that he no longer agrees with the ideologies of the skinheads.The acting in this movie is excellent. Edward Norton played the character of Derek perfectly. In the flashbacks it was almost scary to watch him as he spewed racism and hate. You got the sense that this was real. In playing Danny, Edward Furlong also did a very good job, portraying the younger brother striving for his older brother's affection and respect extremely well. The rest of the supporting characters were also very well done, all the characters seemed believable and you never questioned whether the hate they had was real.While the movie has several small, mainly cosmetic flaws, it is still a very good movie with an inspiring plot line. It is a powerful movie of love and redemption.

Review title: arguably one of the best films ever made
Review_body: Edward Norton stars as Derek Vinyard in American History X (1998); a gripping story of a man who leads a group of young white supremacists. After being released from jail for a brutal hate crime, Derek quickly tries to right the wrongs he's committed in his life before they affect the people he loves. Can Derek save the life of his younger brother Danny, headed down the same direction he has gone, while simultaneously trying to keep himself away from his past and the dangers that come along with it? Edward Norton and Edward Furlong star in this disturbing yet insightful story directed by Tony Kaye. Set in Venice Beach, Kaye shows us a suburban town which is quickly being filled with racial diversity. The tensions between characters are built slowly throughout but not slow enough to take you out of the film. We see this development in much of the movie's lighting techniques. Going from a bright beach town, to the dark backstreets, the movie is defined by Norton's brilliant portrayal of a troubled youth guided down the wrong path of lies and deception. The dialogue is powerful and deals with racism issues that are occurring in American society to this day. Tony Kaye and writer David McKenna are not afraid to push the limits of acceptable language to get their point across. The movie keeps viewers enticed throughout the entire length of the film. Most of the production keeps you on the edge of your seat with an anxious feeling waiting to see what will happen to the characters with whom you seem to gradually develop a connection. The music simply adds to the mood when we listen to orchestrated pieces which leave us with a sense of approaching danger. American History X is a well balanced film with Norton's strong character and his younger brother Danny's innocent yet brain-washed personality. While Furlong is not as convincing of an actor, his performance still has enough to get you lost within the movie. Though the R-rating should be a good enough indication, be aware that the dialogue may be somewhat offensive to some viewers, so it's best to have an open mind throughout the movie. At first, the writer makes you feel as if it is nothing more than a hate-filled movie with no point to the offensive racial slurs. We quickly learn the movie's moral value which overall is what makes the movie a must-see. Through half of the movie, we hear Danny provide narration in the form of an essay which he owes to his history teacher Dr. Sweeny who takes an interest in trying to help Danny and Derek realize the error of their ways. Through this paper we learn a lot about Danny's real emotions and thoughts about his life and the people in it. As Derek tells his story, Kaye uses a black and white display to show flashbacks in the life of Danny and Derek. Through the flashbacks, we slowly learn the reasoning behind the characters' actions and hatred towards other ethnicities. Another great element used are eye-level camera angles which give us a better sense of what is running through Derek's head as he delivers some of the most powerful speeches ever heard in a movie. The movie deserves a 5 out of 5 star rating overall for its portrayal of a racist young man who is only driven by pain and misunderstanding. Though the cinematography may be lacking quality as far as uniqueness goes, it's quickly made up for by one of Edward Norton's best performances of his career. For anyone who enjoys good moral values, the movie is an excellent way to explain how misunderstanding can lead to dire thoughts.

Review title: American History X was a great movie!!!!!
Review_body: The movie American History X explains the life of a former neo-Nazi/ skinhead who is trying to keep his younger brother from becoming a racist and committing the same mistakes he did before he was sent to jail.Derek Vineyard, played by Edward Norton, is a very troubled young man whose father basically raised him to be violent and have hatred against other people of various ethnicities. Actor Avery Brooks also does an outstanding job playing Dr. Bob Sweeny a principal who enforces hard work into his students.The view and the scenery of the movie makes people feel like their part of what's going on the in the movie. It can also be a lesson for younger viewers that using hatred and violence against people can't get you anywhere, so go ahead and watch the movie. You will be amazed.

Review title: My favourite movie of all time :)
Review_body: Absoluly Brilliant!!!! My fav movie of all time without a doubt. This is one of the only movies I can think of that actually makes me feel a bit sad, and I LIKE it :D. Not for the sadness reason, but for the reason that a film can stir up those emotions in me.

Tony Kaye's 1998 film, American History X is a powerful and intelligent look at the Neo-Nazi movement in North America, one man's struggle to escape the group he was involved with and prevent his younger brother from going down the same path he did. It is a phenomenally good film, staying in the viewer's mind long after the credits have rolled. The exceptional directing, music and acting are what make it so memorable.American History X is certainly not the first film to pull out the racism card, nor is it the first film to show change within its characters. It is, however, a story told in such a way that entertains, challenges and moves like no other. A lot can be learned from the story of Derek Vinyard; a man put through various circumstances, is filled with hate and later joins a Neo-Nazi group. Later on, he is imprisoned and despite his initial feelings, eventually befriends a black inmate who challenges his way of thinking. There is a lot that can be learned about humanity through this character, and the later scenes between Derek and Lamont (aforementioned black inmate) are hilarious and heart-warming.Another great thing about American History X is that it never seems overly preachy, but still manages to make its points clear to all those watching and keeps them totally entertained at the same time. Towards the end, the film does an excellent job of showing the negative effects of hate and violence, and how it can still come back to haunt you even after you may have changed.Despite all of the other great points about the film, if there was one thing that could be considered the highlight of American History X, it would have to be the acting. Edward Norton in particular is spectacular as Derek Vinyard. The fact that Norton lost the Academy Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role to Roberto Benigni is flabbergasting. Norton plays the role of Vinyard with ease, being totally believable first as the racist skin head filled with hate and later as a reformed man, desperate to redeem his wrongdoings and stop his brother from making the same mistakes that he did. His performance here is amazing, even topping his portrayal of the complex Narrator in 1999's Fight Club. Certain scenes, such as his arrest after the infamous "curb stomp," leave you mesmerized, all thanks to his talent. Norton's performance in this film would have to be one of the finest examples of acting I have ever seen.Even if they do not compare to Norton's, the performances of the other actors and actresses in this film are nothing to be scoffed at. Edward Furlong does a great job as Derek's brother, Danny Vinyard. He is not as skillful as Norton, but still does a great job of portraying an influenced youth, as well as making it believable that his character could change his views with just a little help from Derek. You can really feel the love between these two brothers and the love that they feel for the rest of their family, which makes certain scenes all the more painful and moving.The actors playing Neo-Nazi characters do a great job as characters you love to hate. These kinds of characters are great when they are both written and played well, and they certainly are here. Stacy Keach is wonderful as the leader of Derek's Neo-Nazi group, Cameron Alexander. Cameron is a lying, cheating racist and Keach does a great job of making the character entertaining and frustrating. Ethan Suplee is always memorable in whatever he does, and American History X proves to be no exception. Seth Ryan is really just another ignorant Neo-Nazi bigot, but Suplee plays the roll in a way that makes the character very entertaining to watch. Faiuza Balk works well as Derek's Neo-Nazi girlfriend, Stacey, who is unopened to the idea of change. William Russ is also worthy of a mention, even if only appearing in one short scene as Derek and Danny's father. This scene is very significant though; as it explains the origins of Derek's hate, and Russ does an excellent job of portraying a man capable of making his son believe in such ideas and ideals. Guy Torry, Avery Brooks, Beverly D'Angelo and Jennifer Lien also deserve mentions for their performances.The atmosphere of this film is dark, helping to add emotion to the moving storyline. The use of black and white in flashback scenes is very atmospheric and useful towards helping us understand what happened when. The soundtrack by Anne Dudley is also very beautiful and adds emotion to many of the scenes, though none of the tracks used in the film are very memorable. Even after watching the film several times, it is unlikely that the audience would remember any of the melodies of the tracks. Though despite this, the music was very pleasant and fitted well with the film.American History X is an amazing film with a good, strong message. The acting, direction and general atmosphere is excellent. The ending is also spot-on, showing that hate does not help make anything better and will only come back to haunt you, making things worse for you and those close to you. It is an exceptional piece of work.

I'm so happy that our teacher made us watch this in school otherwise I would probably never have watched this movie!It's a really powerful movie that shows how it works in a lot of places around the world. You get to see the seriousness of racism and it throws you back a bit when you realize the truth. After watching this movie I was stunned and the entire move was dramatic, intriguing, and beautiful. The actors were amazing and I absolutely recommend this movie to EVERYONE!As an anti Neo-Nazi movie this movie works really powerful. I think that its a really good thing that this movie is often shown in classrooms.

Tony Kaye directed his first feature in "American History X." This film explores deep analysis into the cause of race hatred in the United States. He shows the viewers that different races can look at the same evidence, but draw entirely different answers. In a very shocking, violent, opening scene, teen Danny Vinyard, played wonderfully by Edward Furlong, runs to tell his neo-Nazi brother one evening that a gang of thugs are breaking into his car in front of the house. Derek gets his gun and with no caution shoots the young men in their tracks. Tried and found guilty, Derek is sent away for three (3) years in prison, where he gets a completely different outlook as he compares white-power prisoners with a black prisoner named Lamont, played by Guy Torry. The changes within Derek show the positive impact that Lamont has given to him. Meanwhile, Danny, with a shaved head and a radical attitude, seems determined to follow in his big brother's footsteps. With his new skinhead haircut and eye movements, the viewers can witness the hate which is planted in Danny. After Danny writes a positive review of Adolph Hitler, high school principal Sweeney, puts Danny in a course called American History X and tells him to write a paper about his older brother, who was a past student of Sweeney's. This part is shown by flashbacks, with the movie illustrating Danny's account of Derek's life before the night of the shooting.The main themes that are shown in the movie are affirmative action and racism. The theme of affirmative action is mostly shown through the character of Derek's father. These themes are shown throughout the whole film.The performances of Edward Norton and Edward Furlong are unbelievable. Edward Norton shows the ability to demonstrate the hatred and development of his character quite convincing. Edward Furlong plays the "narrator" and character of Danny. He also shows the development of his character.The story of "American History X" is healing and opens the mind that racism does happen and we never really see how damaging it can be to oneself and others. The film makes it point quite well and gives the message clearly. The director, Tony Kaye, refuses the movie to have a happy ending. With racism and the consequences of it, this kind of behavior can destroy family members for life (i.e. tragedy built from hate and ignorance).

Review title: Violent film about a neo-Nazi gang leader
Review_body: The story evolves around two brothers, Derek Vinyard (Edward Norton) and Danny Vinyard (Edward Furlong) growing up in Los Angeles. Derek becomes involved with a Neo-Nazi gang after his father who was a fireman is killed by a black man while putting out a fire. With an intense rage and hatred for other races and cultures Derek quickly rises through the ranks of the gang. Then one night three black gang members try to steal his pickup truck, but Derek is there to thwart the attempt and ends up brutally killing two of the gang members. Because of the killing Derek is sent away to prison for three years. While there Derek joins the other neo-Nazi inmates, but gets in a argument and is raped by his own gang members. Afterwards Derek is virtually alone except for his one friend Lamont (Guy Torry) a black co-worker in the laundry, who helps him stay safe for the rest of his sentence. After getting released from prison Derek comes home with a new view on race, but finds out that Danny has become very involved with the neo-Nazi gang. Derek is determined to get Danny out of the gang, but is too late when Danny is shot and killed by a black gang member. American History X tries to show the social problems that are being faced in the poorer neighborhoods of Los Angeles. Similar to Boyz-n the Hood (1991) it shows the violent environment of the inner city with gangs and racial tension. In both of these movies the main characters are intelligent young men who realize that they must get out of this environment before it is too late, and they end up getting killed. After getting in trouble for writing a paper on Mien Kaumf Danny Vinyard (Edward Furlong) is instructed by the principal of his school Mr. Sweeney (Avery Brooks) to write a paper about his brother Derek (Edward Norton) who was the leader of a neo-Nazi gang before being sent away for three years for murder. In telling the story the director Tony Kaye uses black and white film to show the flashback in time, and narration from Danny to help tell the story of Derek. The black and white filming helps the viewer in realizing what a flashback is and what is happening in the present. Additionally the black and white adds suspense to the film, and to provide an abstract look at Derek's evil past. The narration or voice over by Danny provides the viewer with a better understanding of what is going on in Derek's life when the flashback occurs.

Review title: The director hits the social problem of racism head on and leaves us spellbound by the reality of his depiction.
Review_body: In the movie American History X, directed by Tony Kaye, the audience learns from the story of two brothers the hardships and root of ignorant racial views. The tale is told from the narration of the misguided youngest brother Danny Vinyard, played by Edward Furlong. During the opening scene the audience gains a full appreciation of the limitless boundaries of racial prejudice and hate. Danny is awoken by two black men breaking into his brother's car so he goes to interrupts his older brother Derek, played by Edward Norton. As Derek tosses his girlfriend off of him we quickly learn his characters radical racial views. With a large swastika on the wall of his bedroom and tattooed to his chest, we realize he is the epitome of a neo-Nazi skinhead. From the anger of his father's death at the hands of a minority and the misguided teaching of his neo-Nazi mentor Cameron Alexander, played by Stacy Keach, Derek unleashes his rage on the two black gang-bangers ultimately landing him in prison for manslaughter. With his best friend and idol Derek in jail, Danny is destined to fall into his brothers footsteps, unless influenced by his principle Dr. Sweeney, played by Avery Brooks, who gives him an assignment of writing a paper on the events surrounding his recently released brother's incarceration. From the beginning of the movie, the director transitions from color to the black and white effectively to capture the significance and realization of Danny and Derek's memories. It is through the memories of Danny we learn about Derek's progression of violence toward minorities. During Danny's quest to fully understand his brother, whose view and opinions have changed since leaving jail, we learn from Derek firsthand about his time behind bars. This technique helps the audience gain a full appreciation of Derek's progression towards hate and his harsh time in prison because it does not glorify what is depicted on screen. During Derek's incarceration he finds out his follow skinheads aren't all that courageous and turns his back on them. For his disrespect they rape him violently in the shower and threaten his life. With no protection and everyone out to get him he forms an unlikely bond with a black inmate and seeks the guidance of his old teacher Dr. Sweeney. Once release from jail Derek begins his journey to leave behind his old ways and educate his younger brother. Although he travels the streets with the same paranoia from prison he may be too late to save Danny from meaningless racially motivated hate crimes. American History X is filmed with the subjective view point similar to that of Gran Torino, directed by Clint Eastwood. The director puts you right into the emotions of the character as they struggle towards learning that their cause is an ignorant ambition. This technique allows us to see firsthand the intimacies of racism and prejudice as both brothers grow to understand the realities of their beliefs. The director hits the social problem of racism head on and leaves us spellbound by the reality of his depiction.

American History X is a story about two brothers, Derek Vinyard (Edward Norton) and a black drug dealer while fighting a fire in a neighborhood in Los Angeles murdered Daniel Vinyard (Edward Furlong), who fight racism after their father, who was a firefighter. Derek goes to prison for 3 years after brutally killing black gang members who he catches breaking into his families car. Daniel follows his brother's footstep until Derek gets out of prison and tries to stop Daniel from going down the same path. Derek finally gets Daniel on the right path and Daniel is dropped off at school where a black kid shoots him in the bathroom; a black kid that Daniel had confrontation with earlier in the film. The theme of the film is about racism. The family battles it after a black drug dealer killed their father. The movie focuses on problems and conflicts between the family and black people. There is a scene where Derek organizes a raid on a foreign owned grocery store. He organizes people to go into this store and raid it, tearing up the inside in the process and confronting the owners. In the beginning of the film Derek kills, black gang members after they are caught breaking into his family's car. He shots at them, then makes a man put his teeth on the curb, and kicks the back of his head. Derek is then arrested. Daniel follows Derek's footsteps and joins the white supremacist. While Derek is in jail, Dr. Sweeny (Avery Brooks) visits him and Avery convinces him that racism is pointless. Derek realizes that the only reason he stayed alive in prison was a black person that he became close friends with. Time in prison was life changing for Derek and he was determined to change the family's lives when he got out. Derek and Daniel were committed to a better lifestyle without racism when Derek drops Daniel off a school Daniel goes into the bathroom and is confronted by a black boy from the previous day. They look each other in the eye and Daniel is shot to death right in the bathroom. American History X and Crash are identical in theme and plot. They both are about people who are racist in the beginning but then open up by the end of the movie. Both of these movies start out harsh in relevance to racism and by the end, all people are getting along. The lighting and color choice were very appropriate for this film. The film went from color to black and white, which was appropriate for the scenes they were showing. For example, the scene where Derek shots the gang members is black and white and I think it added feeling and dramatization to the scene. The color scenes were not overly bright which sets the mood for the film and how Derek's family is unhappy and racist. The lighting was not very bright and was dull throughout the movie. Both the lighting and color choice set the mood and tone of the entire movie. The motif in this film was the swastika as it was portrayed throughout the film. It was tattooed on Derek's chest, it was on posters in Derek and Daniel's room and it was seen many times throughout the movie. This shows or proves that the movie is about racism and white supremacists. This symbol was a fit for the theme of the movie and it was evident when they were taking there posters down that they were going to attempt a better life and a life without racism in it. This was an excellent movie and I enjoyed it however, I feel that it was very violent and should not be viewed by everyone. Not every individual can handle this film because of the graphic nature and the extent of the violence and the language. I think that everything was needed to get the theme across but once again; I would not recommend this movie to everyone especially if you are easily offended.

Although the core of the movie is gritty and a very harsh subject to touch on, all actors and director pulled it off. Full of raw emotion that will have you questioning your perception of what racism has actually done to this society. Stacey Keach makes you hate him. Edward Norton makes you hate him, then root for him, and then sympathize with his character. Edward Furlong pulls off a great performance as well as a young man trying to find what his beliefs actually are. Surprise under the radar movie that just brought so much emotion to the screen. Sadly I hardly ever hear this movie brought up in many conversations as an excellent movie, but it should be.

Review title: A reformed Neo-Nazi hopes to change his brother's life.
Review_body: American History X is a film about a guy who was a former Neo-Nazi who changed his life after doing a 3 year sentence in prison. This guy Derrek Vinyard, played by Edward Norton, has a younger brother Danny, played by Edward Furlong, who is basically going down the same road as Derrek did before jail. Derrek tries to prevent this from happening. Derek's deviant behavior had great influence on his little brother. Derrek was the leader of a gang of white supremacists in which committed racial crimes. Derrek's reason for going to prison was for killing three guys who tried to steal his truck in his yard. Oh, not to mention, the 3 guys were black. This film shows that no matter what a person has done in their past, change and forgiveness is possible. This film's story is told through Danny in the form of a paper through use of flashbacks. The purpose of this was because Danny wrote a paper for class that was not approved and Dr. Sweeny, played by Avery Brooks, made him rewrite the paper. This paper was to be about his brother's life. The editor's use of flashbacks and montages make this a film to be seen. The use of sound effects and customs are very effective and helps the film become real. The up close angles and the flashbacks encourage the viewing to be on edge and on point. This is a must see movie. The superb acting and the music behind each scene makes this movie of racial crime and reformation a must see movie. I will not spoil it for you, but of course all drama films have a twist.

Review title: American History X is a film that both glorifies and humanizes racism.
Review_body: Released In: 1998 Main Characters: Derek Vinyard (Edward Norton), Daniel "Danny" Vinyard (Edward Furlong), Murray (Elliott Gould), Dr. Sweeny (Avery Brooks)American History X is a film that both glorifies and humanizes racism. Derek Vinyard, Danny Vinyard's older brother was in the neo-Nazi "movement" due to past experiences with the loss of his father. Derek's father was firefighter who was killed trying to protect others, protecting an African American home and lost his life. This in sighted a rage in Derek, therefore affecting his entire family. This rage affected Derek's thought process and he felt as if he was doing what was right in society. Derek ended up going to prison and serving time for his outrageous acts. This is when Derek came to see the error of his ways. Derek met an African American, who befriended him in prison. This man allowed Derek to see things a little differently. Derek then returned home, hoped to change the ways that he had established within his family, with this return; he found the complete opposite. American History X has an overall theme of something everyone can relate to, making amends for past transgressions; more specifically the love of two brothers and the care for they have for one another. Another major theme that many people see within this film is racism. Racism is a major concern. Derek was the leader of the racist side within his community before his imprisonment. Derek influences many of his followers throughout this film. His followers were dissolution impressionable youths with weak family ties, had few friends, and needed to be a part of something. Danny, Derek's brother was one of the many who were affected by this strong organizer. This system appeared to be organized and was something that many were doing. However when Derek was imprisoned he had the capabilities to see African Americans as humans beings versus vicious animals. By doing this, his impression changed completely. Derek wanted nothing more for his brother to see the other side. Derek tired immensely to change Danny, however struggled. Danny began to see the truth in Derek's ways, Danny's heart and mind were changing. Danny tried to make amends with the African American boys in his school. Danny was strong minded, however not as strong minded as the African Americans. They were still acting out in rage like both Derek and Danny used to. In the end, Danny was murdered. Danny was killed by the African American, who was raised just like Danny. This African American boy did not and was not ready to make amends and see that all are equal. The theme of American History X can directly relate to the movie "Crash". Both of these films have a great deal of racism. Along with racism, making amends for past transgressions. The angle and lighting immensely relate to the theme of American History X. The film is shot in black and white that clearly conveyed one of the main themes racial tensions between blacks and whites. There are several scenes where the camera angle also conveys the theme; when Derek speaks throughout the film they focused on the swastika on his chest; he was proud to show it. In contrast in prison he was not, he became ashamed. In conclusion, the efforts glorify the racist movement failed. Derek saw the humanity in his prison friends. Derek began to have an understanding and love for many people; with his change in heart, he hoped to influence others.

Review title: Capacity to change, racial issues, social injustices
Review_body: Danny Vinyard played by Edward Furlong was a teenage boy who submitted an essay paper in class declaring his opinion of praise on the book Mein Kampf by Adolf Hitler. The teacher whom Danny submitted the paper to was Jewish. The principle summoned Danny in for a meeting telling him he is going to redo his assignment but with a different objective and twenty four hours to do it in. The task is a full essay on how his life has been shaped by the events that have taken place including the events that took place to land his brother Derek Vinyard played by Edward Norton in prison. The day Danny met with principle and assigned his new objective was the day that Derek is released from prison. Derek became very involved in a white supremacist group and his hatred for humans with color was intense. One night Derek's vehicle was being broken in to and he goes out and catches the guys, he killed themhe went to prison. While in prison Derek's job paired him with a black man and over time they become close and Derek changes. Derek's change is the prime example to the prominent theme of the moviethe capacity of oneself to change. The movie deals with the life of Danny and Derek Vinyard and some crucial issues that deal with racism and social injustices. The themes of the movie are the ability to change yourself, racism issues, and social injustices. The motif and symbols seen throughout the movie were very relevant to the theme. The Mein Kampf, the posters, and the tattoos were all relevant to the theme of the movie. The dialogue to the movie was very appropriate and stayed right in line with the themes. The movie American History X was a great movie that dealt this issues that always seem to be issues at least in the past and present the issue of racism and social injustices have always been a problem and could be a problem in the future. I like how this movie showed the hatred, anger, and violence within a family and within the society but this movie showed all the gritty details and scenes that were full of hate but it also showed the consequences of decisions and the light at the end of the dark tunnel.

My friend also suggested this film and i thought it was a stunning, and great film, It sucked me right in from the start. Edward Norton played a great performance,and so did Furlong, One of the best movies that I have ever seen, this movie gets a 10 / 10

Review title: Life is more than black and white.
Review_body: All is not well down by the beach. Local teenager and Venice Beach High School student Daniel Vinyard (Edward Furlong) is on the same slippery slope his older brother, Derek Vinyard (Edward Norton), was on. After their fire fighter father, Dennis (William Russ), was murdered while putting out a blaze at a known drug den, young Derek was molded and guided by Cameron Alexander (Stacie Keach), a local white supremacist. Derek became the charismatic leader of the local neo-Nazi gang, the DOC. Here he recruited the scared and disenfranchised white kids in the neighborhood who were tired of living in fear of the growing local minority dominate gangs. Now, Derek has just been released from prison after serving time for the murder of 2 black, local gang members, who were trying to steal his car. As an older, wiser Derek emerges from prison, has he been released in time to save his family from the wide reaching grip of violence and racial tensions created by his own rhetoric? Director Tony Kaye's use of color wasn't to just simply help the viewer understand scenes that take place in the present and scenes that happen in the past. The motive of color goes deeper, as the present day scenes of color show us how Derek now views the world, with all its color and diversity. This is a stark contrast from the Derek of the past, whose view was much narrower and he saw the world as simple as black and white. Also, the use of low-key lighting during the past and the racially charged scene shows the clouded views of hate that Derek and others have of their surrounding world. Racially charged films show how their characters justify their hate. Much like Clint Eastwood's film, Gran Torino, the main character, Walt, drew his hatred for minorities from his war experiences. In American History X, Derek's hate was driven, in most part, by the senseless murder of his father (Morrissey & Kaye, 1998). This racially charged film shows that the world we live in isn't as simple as black and white.

American History X is an enlightening film about race, violence, and learning acceptance. Edward Norton gives a phenomenal performance as Derek Vineyard, an influential white supremacist. This is not a role I would imagine for Norton, but he makes the character completely believable. Edward Furlong plays the perfect struggling teen, Danny Vineyard, who is trying to find himself and fit-in at the same time. Derek is sent to prison for murder, while Danny is left behind to follow in Derek's footsteps. Derek learns a great deal about people and stereotypes during his three year incarceration. He eventually wishes a different life for Danny. With the help of one of his former teachers, he realizes that nothing he has done as the leader of his skinhead crew has made his life better. Instead of finding solutions to problems, he had been perpetuating a cycle of violence.This movie gives viewers a detailed look at racism and prejudice in our country. There is great use of flashbacks, shown in black and white, to provide a glimpse of how things came to be the way they are. The opening flashback scene was very powerful, giving an understanding of Derek's pride and his importance to Danny. Narration by Danny is also instrumental in letting the audience have an inside look at the Vineyard family. He looks up to his older brother and has seen some truth in Derek's views.This movie shares some common characteristics with the film Gran Torino. Both movies are led by racists white men who seem to make no exceptions when it comes to their hatred of minority races. It takes the development of a personal relationship with someone of color to make the men reconsider their preconceived notions. Derek comes to befriend his black coworker in prison. He realizes that it is not race that makes a person good or bad, and he learns that injustices do exist for minorities in our society.The end of the film is ironic but depressing. After Derek shares his epiphany with his younger brother, the violent cycle continues. Danny is shot and killed by a young black boy who used to be a target of Danny's hatred. Just when Danny may have been able to see the boy with different eyes, his chance is taken away. Derek blames himself for being such a strong influence in Danny's life. He can take his life in a new direction, but he can't change what has already been done.

Review title: One of the major themes of this film is race relations, and racism
Review_body: The film American History X was released in 1998 by director Tony Kaye. One of the major themes of this film is race relations, and racism. The film is based on how races relate and how people see things the way they want when they are hurt by people of a certain race. In the film Derek Vinyard played by Edward Norton is very frustrated about life and the fact that a black man took his father away from him by murdering him in cold blood. Derek could never get over it, and he wanted revenge. Derek is sent to prison for killing two black men who tried to steal his vehicle.When Derek is released from prison after serving 3 years in prison he is changed his outlook about racism, but for Derek he will have to face it again, and through his younger brother Danny who is played by Edward Furlong a young lost soul who is following in his brothers footsteps. The film is very intense and very graphic you are able to see the way white supremacist act against other races.The film shows black and white scenes which represents Derek's pass and how he ends up where he is in life. It helps bring life and understanding to the film. The lightning in the film is both high and low depending on the scene of the film. The low key lightning is used to show dark and evil hatred that the white supremacist has against other races.This film can also be compared to the film Higher Learning which is also about racism and race relations. American History X is a must see film it is the sociological imagination of a white male who has reacted in a very negative way due to his past.

Review title: The most powerful film of the '90s.
Review_body: To tell you the truth, this movie is the most powerful movie I have ever seen, however I have not seen enough movies to call this work the most powerful of all time.  The performances in this movie all show how much the actors really understood modern-day racism and all that comes with it.  It is hard to believe that within a couple of hours, Edward Norton could turn from a skinhead killer into a noble big brother to Edward Furlong who also showed his abilities in this movie.  Kudos also to Beverly D'Angelo for making such a troubled mother still love her children.  This movie is not a must see-it is a must own!

Review title: BEST MOVIE OF ALL TIME (oscar snubbed)
Review_body: Plot:After a black man murdered his dad, Derek Vinyard becomes angry at all opposing races.  As an impressionable, smart, young man he is mentored by a white supremacist.  He then finds other angry white teens to join his new gang, called the Skinheads (they all shave their heads).  The gang is meant for white males who are sick and tired of getting beaten up by black and hispanic gangs.  Although this gang does not help out Derek, and he commits a brutal murder, which gets him landed in jail.  When he gets out his perspective changes completely, and throws away his white supremity notions. But he now finds that his younger brother Danny is following in his footsteps.  Can he save Danny before it is too late?"Some legacies must end."Cast:Edward Norton - Derek VinyardEdward Furlong - Danny VinyardStacy Keach - Cameron AlexanderReviewer's Take:I give it a 9.9 and says "Edward Norton puts on an incredible show.  This movie is so powerful.  Everything is just so real and you feel like everything is real.  The plot was just incredible, and I think that the direction of this movie was amazing as well.  I really hope that everyone sees this movie."

This movie, or film since it surpasses many other movies, provoked more thought from me than any other movie has.  I finished the movie having a temporary new look upon the world.  My ideals were questioned, my morals challenged.  Ed Norton is incredible.  He had to have done hours of research into his part to become the true Neo Nazi. Wonderful film.

I was skeptical before watching this film because of the delicate material, that it deals with. However after seeing this film, it one of the best films I have ever seen. The story of racists white man(Norton) who after a stint in prision, renouces his racist ways and pro-nazi attitude is stunning. It is wonderfully direct with the flashback technique working wonders and strong performances by the cast. what elevates this film to a whole new level though is the performance of Edward Norton. He recieved a Academy award nomination and it is richly deserved. Almost certainly the best performance of his carear, although in his latest film, 25th hr he also turns in a brillant performnce.There are vilolent themes, sex scenes, course language and adult themes, so it may not be for everyone. But it is a brilliant film that should be viewed by anyone who appreciates good film.

Review title: What a Great Film. Everyone Should See This
Review_body: It's amazing when I hear people say they didn't like this movie - one, no one ever says that, and two, it's a cinematic masterpiece if I've ever seen one. Everything flows together in a way that only the Scorceses and Spielbergs can pull off. I really felt connections to the characters as they developed, something that has been all but lost in modern filmmaking. Derek Vinyard's life is chronicled in such a way that you can almost draw parallels to your own; I thought about all of the things I've done that hurt other people, which in comparison were hardly that bad, of course, but the fact that even someone as evil and brainwashed as himself can be redeemed and be a small instrument of what is good about humanity is enlightening, if not humbling.Detractors of the film claim that his transformation is too extreme to be taken seriously, a product of amateur screen writing and a false sense of morality, but I argue just the opposite. No matter how far someone has fallen, there is always a glimmer of hope, and sometimes it just takes a new form of stimuli for them to realize it.
This film was Monsterous! One of my favorite films

Review title: Life is short, so why waste it on an emotion like hatred.
Review_body: The 1998 film American History X is about a family that is torn apart by the roots of race hatred within America. This story focuses on Danny Vinyard (Edward Fulong) who is in a white supremacist group which his brother Derek (Edward Norton) had once led. In the movie, Danny had written an English paper on Mein Kampf and now has to redo the paper and write about Derek. He has to analyze and interpret the events that had surrounded Derek's incarceration and how it had impacted his view on life and his family. Through Danny's writing the audience learns that Derek was the leader of the group and had committed crimes of a racial nature throughout Los Angeles. Now, Derek had just finished serving a three year jail sentence for manslaughter, for when he shot, killed, and curb stomped some African American youths for stealing his father's truck. Throughout the story, as Danny writes his paper, he reflects on all the events that had led up to Derek's arrest. Such as the trashing of Archie's Ranch Market, the violence at dinner, and the treatment of his family. However, what Danny does not understand is that during Derek's time in prison he had made friends with an African American named Lamont (Guy Torry), and had acquired a new outlook on life. Danny does eventually learn of Derek's new found look on life and in turn he too decides to leave the cult behind in search for something better not only for him but for his family.This movie had been brilliantly presented by the director Tony Kaye. Through the black and white flashbacks accessible throughout the story, the audience really gets to focus in on what is happening during the scenes, and are able to achieve a deeper sense of depth to the story. The lighting and angles used also had improved the visual perspective, which coupled with the use of the development of the characters to convey the message had greatly enhanced the movie as a whole. In the end, what the viewers are to take away from this movie is the fact that even though the story did not preach about it directly, it is about racism and the hatred that is created from it. The movie is closely related to another movie called In the Heat of the Night which also carries the themes of racism and murder. People should not allow the hatred to consume their lives and essentially destroy not only themselves but also their family. Life is short, so why waste it on an emotion like hatred.

I watched 'American History X' at a time in my life when I was thinking deeply about all the facets of racism and how it arises from the environments we are born into. I'm happy to say his film not only confirmed my own thoughts on these subjects but gave me even more insight into this worldwide problem. Being a white female who is probably still quite naive about racism because none of it ever comes my way, I am glad about the things I learned from this film. I find it interesting (and depressing) how so many movies and TV shows out there seem to glorify this idea of 'retribution' or vigilantism; the idea that one is not only righteous in murdering someone who has wronged them/harmed their family, but they gain respect from their peers (or those viewing the film)for doing so. Until I watched American History X I was yet to find a film that glorified forgiveness and change. For most of my life, I myself did not understand the concept of forgiveness, and unquestioningly believed in things like capital punishment, like many others around me (thankfully, I don't anymore!) What I love and relate to in this film is that it illustrates that every person, even those furtherest into their own beliefs, can change, and should be given the chance to do so. Some may say that the ending is cliché, but honestly I think when it comes to films with a message like this one, such observations are irrelevant and mundane. The ending was vital to the overall point of the film because it serves as a warning. At the risk of sounding cliché myself, the end of this film warns us not to carry on the cycle of violence, but to forgive, and let people change. It's called evolution :)

American History X is a 1998 drama film directed by Tony Kaye, starring Edward Norton and Edward Furlong. The film tells the story of two brothers, Derek Vinyard and Daniel "Danny" Vinyard from Venice Beach in Los Angeles, California. They are both smart and charismatic boys. Their father, who was formally a firefighter, was murdered by a black drug dealer while trying to fight a fire in a South Central neighborhood of Los Angeles, and Derek is drawn into this whole neo-Nazi movement. In the movie older brother Derek kills two black gang members who he catches in the act of breaking into the truck left to him by his father, and is sentenced to three years in prison for voluntary manslaughter. The story shows how Danny is influenced by his older brother's actions and mindset and how Derek, now suddenly changed by his experience in prison, which includes a violent rape scene by white inmates.This is a very controversial film and is bound to spark up a ton of conversation. While watching this film it is best to have an open mind set so that feeling or cultural preferences don't interfere with the point that the movie is trying to make.

The film, American History X, written by David McKenna, is about a young man who goes from being a skinhead, Neo-Nazi supremacist to attempting to save his brother from following down the same path of destruction. After the death of his father by a black drug-dealer, Derek Vinyard (Edward Norton) finds himself proactive in a Neo-Nazi gang led by Cameron Alexander (Stacy Keach) and right next to him is his girlfriend Stacey (Fairuza Balk). One evening Derek's younger brother Danny Vinyard (Edward Furlong) alerts Derek that some black guys were trying to break into his vehicle. Derek darts outside shooting a gun, killing one of them and forcing another to "bite the curb" where he kills him as well. As Danny looks on, his brother is arrested, charged, and sentenced to three years in prison. Derek learns in prison that he was wrong in believing and acting the way he did when he leaves the safety of the gang in prison he joined and befriended a black man Lamont (Guy Torry). Danny is following in his brother's footsteps by: joining the same gang, writing papers such as Mein Kampf, and openly being a skinhead, Neo-Nazi supremacist. Dr. Bob Sweeney (Avery Brooks) from Danny's school visits Derek in prison to inform him that Danny is following in his footsteps. When Derek gets out of prison, he tries everything he can to reach out to Danny to make his see what he did was wrong and it's not something to be proud of. Once he gets through to Danny and they both vow to stay away from that kind of evil, Danny gets killed in the bathroom by a black man he had an argument with earlier in the film. The theme of this film is the ability to change oneself. Throughout the film there are flashbacks from Danny's point of view as well as Derek's when he is in prison. The story shows how events that happen in a person's life can ultimately change how they view themselves enough to change who they are when they realize that reflection they are looking at every day is not the person they want to be. With the theme in mind another film that I feel shows how people can change and view life in a different was is "The Shawshank Redemption" where two men who are in prison for different crimes learn that friendship and kindness can make life so much more worthwhile. The lighting, color, and angles used throughout the film helped to captivate the audience. When there were flashbacks the use of black and white was amazing to show the overall difference between past and present. The angle used when Derek was being arrested was to make sure the audience not only saw the outcome, but ultimately see the expression on Derek's face when he was looking at Danny and smiling. That was the last memory Danny had of him outside of prison. When addressing the theme on changing oneself, sometimes it takes a person to step back and look at how things were when there was happiness and innocence. One scene was where Derek is looking in the mirror and thinks about when he and Danny were very young. To that point he realizes how much pain he has caused many people around him, and what needs to be done in hopes to fix what he continued from the hatred his father taught him.
Amazing cinematography, very heavy subject matter and insightful view of an dark side of our society.

Review title: American History X is a film about the negativity and worthlessness of hatred and racism.
Review_body: American History X is a film about the negativity and worthlessness of hatred and racism.Edward Norton who plays Derek, the proclaimed leader of a Neo-Nazi Skinhead gang in Los Angeles during the racially fueled time period of the Rodney King Trail, attempts to free himself and his family from the empire he has helped to create, after his release from prison. Derek's imprisonment which was caused by his role in the murder of two African Americans who were attempting to steal his vehicle yields him three years behind bars on manslaughter charges.Danny played by Edward Furlong, is Derek's younger brother who idolizes Derek after the death of their father. Caught in the same racist thinking traps, the film captures his racially fueled dialog and dramatic scenes to highlight the uncomfortable interactions he has with other races. Naturally Danny starts to grow closer to Derek's friends while he is in prison and begins to get noticed by the watchful eye of Cameron played Stacy Keach. Cameron, whose original vision helped Derek to organize and form the gang he led, is trying to recruit Danny through verbal manipulation in an effort to continue growing the organization.In the film the director uses a technique of switching from black and white to color as a way to delineate between past and present, while dramatizing the scene. As the film progresses, we notice Derek experience a great transformation away from racism, through the unlikely pairing of an African American prisoner (Lamont) played by Guy Torry, when they are both assigned to the same work detail. During the course of Derek's transformation he starts to understand that his chosen path only leads to destruction and the demise of his family. Faced with these new challenges upon release, Derek has to figure out how best to get his life back together along with his family. Derek comes home to less than optimal living conditions while mother, Doris played by Beverly D'Angelo is ill and can't afford to care for the family. Derek notices the toll his choices have taken on his family, more enlightened, Derek want nothing but a better life for his family to include his younger brother who is dangerously close to following wrong crowd, which leads to Derek's attempt to convince Cameron to leave him and his family alone.

American History X is a movie which follows the life of a Neo-Nazi skinhead Derek Vinyard (Ed Norton) that develops a hatred for any race other than his own. He soon finds himself in prison for killing two black men caught breaking into his truck. During his prison time, he begins to question his prejudices as he makes friends with a black man named Lamont (Guy Torry). Once released from prison, he dedicates himself to convincing his younger brother Danny Vinyard (Edward Furlong) that being a part of a supremacist group is wrong. The story attempts to show how being a part of a supremacist group can brainwash someone into unbelievable hatred for a person based on their color of skin. The unbelievable change that Derek makes in prison is hard to accept from his friends and family. He is soon cast out of the group and finds himself alone. Danny is described as a brilliant teenager that has been led down the wrong path in life. The principle in the school, Dr. Bob Sweeney (Avery Brooks) takes it upon himself to attempt to identify why Danny feels the way he does. Before Danny is able to show that he is changing, a tragic event unfolds. This movie has a strange similarity to the film Gran Torino. Both movies touch on a specific person that has years of hatred and prejudice for other races. The relationships developed from both main characters to people of other races shows that feelings can be changed and friendships made. In each of these movies, death represents what the cost of prejudice can be. Main characters in each of these movies die as a result of an unfortunate hatred. There were recurring ideas (motifs) throughout both movies. The indescribable prejudice that one person can have and their ability to see what is right and overcome that feeling. Many close up angles throughout the films attempt to show emotion and feeling without necessarily having dialogue. In American History X, there were many "skinheads" that displayed Nazi symbols in the form of tattoos and flags to represent their outspoken prejudices. In Gran Torino, the constant derogatory language that was used displayed the same emotion. American History X was an interesting look at a life many people do not live. The ability to understand why someone would have such hatred is shown in a way that the viewer would relate to. The underlying theme is the ability to overcome a life of hatred and see that we are all created equal.

Review title: American History X can bring the best of us to tears
Review_body: Be warned! Anyone who begins to watch this film without the open mind that is needed, risks the chance of disliking what is probably the most powerful movie they may ever see. Indeed this film is not for the faint hearted, who will turn away at the first sign of obscenity. Nor is it for the narrow-minded ones amongst us, who will never appreciate the greatness this film has to offer. "Hate is baggage", arguably the most meaningful message brought to us in this film through the outstanding performances of Edward Norton (Derek Vineyard)and Edward Furlong (his brother- Danny). Danny is a young but intellectual English student at high school but also an apprentice of the local racist leader Cameron Alexander (Stacey Keach). Derek, a major figure in the "White Power" movement is the murderer of two black would-be robbers and the influential role model of his baby brother. The plot begins to unfold when Derek is released from prison after serving his time. Apparently transformed whilst inside, on his release he is devastated to learn that Danny has adopted his brothers wicked neo-Nazi ways. It is now Derek's duty as the older brother to alter the strong and narrow opinions that Danny has before something drastic is allowed to happen. The brutality, language, sexuality and heavy cultural influence are all appropriate if not necessary in bringing across the overall message of this film as one of positive redemption.A truly marvellous experience, two thumbs up!

In American History X, Derek Vineyard (played by Edward Norton) is a self proclaimed Neo-Nazi (skin head) and a leader of a gang, fostered by a preacher of hate, Cameron Alexander (Stacy Keach). Alexander, who uses impressionable kids but stays behind the scenes to keep himself out of trouble, teaches hatred of anyone that is a minority and further pushes Derek into believing in white supremacy and uses Derek's skills and intelligence to help spread his word of hate. Thanks to his intelligence and skills in speaking, others follow Derek in terrorizing anyone who is not white as shown when Derek and other skinheads go into the Korean grocery store. Derek's first hint of racism came from his father, who was killed in the line of duty by a minority. This is where Derek began to have hatred for all minorities and was able to be easily influenced by the likes of Alexander. Derek has a younger brother Danny (Edward Furlong) that idolizes him and wants to emulate him, and his mother Doris (Beverly D'Angelo) and sister Davin (Jennifer Lien) who both are afraid of Derek but are also afraid of the life he has chosen and where that choice will take him. This theme of violence is not unlike the one shown by the Hmong gang that was terrorizing the community in Detroit in the film Gran Torino (Eastwood, 2008). After Derek was sentenced to prison for happily murdering two black youths that was breaking into his vehicle, things for Derek changed. While serving his sentence, he learned that there are good and bad people of every race and his view of others unlike himself have changed. Upon his release from prison, Derek must pull his younger brother from the mire of hatred that he once embraced. This feeling of hate and racism is one of the primary themes in the movie, and the easiest for the viewer to understand. Racism and hatred are both powerfully shown in this film but it ends with the enlightenment of Derek that what he has done in the past, and where his brother Danny is heading in the future, is wrong. There were many techniques used to show the power of the scenes. From using flashbacks to show what happened in the past to change Derek both negatively and positively, and the narration of the film by Danny, it all helped to tell the story the director wished the viewer to see. Plot points that supported the theme of violence and racism included the symbol of the Nazi swastika on Derek's chest. In the beginning, he wore that tattoo with pride but after maturing and becoming enlightened in prison, he wore it with shame. Camera angles were such that fear of the gang was shown by those that were terrorized by them and probably one of the most powerful was showing the violence of Derek killing the two men. American History X shows that there are consequences to the actions one takes and that enlightenment comes at a cost. For Derek, that cost was the time he spent in prison and what happened to him there.

Review title: Released on parole after murdering two black men, a neo-Nazi attempts to reform.
Review_body: American History X is a fine film, which has at its dark centre a towering performance that establishes Edward Norton as the most promising character actor of his generation.Told through the eyes of his admiring brother (a perfectly cast Furlong), American History X charts the rise, if that's the right word, of Derek Vinyard (Norton) a fiercely intelligent young man who, after the shooting of his father by a black man, and encouraged by sinister good ol' boy Cameron (Stacy Keach), shaves his head, has a swastika tattooed on his chest and proceeds to galvanise the local disenchanted youth into forming a racist gang before murdering two black men who were attempting to steal his car. When Derek returns on parole after three years of his sentence, his brother David (Furlong), whose doe-eyed puppyish looks bely his own gestating violent racism, is horrified to find that his brother has been reformed in jail and has not only grown back his mane but is determined to redress some of the harm he has done. Which is not a policy popular with his gang, which has gathered to welcome him back as a conquering hero.Neo-Nazidom has a short though distinguished history on the big screen. Alan Clarke's Made In Britain and Australian director Geoffrey Wright's Romper Stomper both took an uncomfortable look inside the heads of racist thugs. Yet American History X's strength is not its subject matter but Edward Norton's ballistic performance. Despite a weak backstory (Derek's rage apparently having its genesis in childhood after a few bigoted comments uttered by his dad, while his equally implausible moral reversal comes from "meeting a nice black fella" in jail), Norton manages to deliver one of the most convincing racists ever while retaining his character's humanity. Even after he kills - and in doing so commits to celluloid one of the most sadistically shocking acts of violence in the medium's history (if, that is, all the footage of this pre-release cut survives the attentions of the BBFC) - Norton manages to preserve the shred of humanity that carries us through his redemption and prevents us from simply dismissing him as worthless scum.Kaye's direction occasionally veers a little too close to his advertising roots; extensive use of slo-mo - particularly, for some reason, in showers that begin to resemble shampoo ads - and black- and-white lend a chic patina, which some may think is a little overcooked. And, in between set pieces, he flounders slightly, though this may be a symptom of the re-edit. Another may be the ending, in which Kaye seems to lose faith with the power of his own movie and delivers what could be seen as a cheap twist in place of a considered conclusion.But in themselves the set pieces are astonishing. A brutal attack on a convenience store, a gruelling prison rape sequence, and a dinner party argument that erupts into violence are all edited with sustained barnstorming energy.

Review title: The journey of one white supremacists through some life-changing events and the impact they have on his life and those around him.
Review_body: American History X is a film that brings out the ugly side of prejudice and white supremacy. The name of the film comes from Danny's principal who asks him to write a paper on his brother Derek's lifestyle as a white supremacist. Derek is the gang leader of the supremacist group in his town and always seems proud to show off the swastika tattoo on his chest.I believe the theme of this film is how racism and white supremacy affect a society and how people can change their views by learning more about one another. For Derek, this change does not come easy, and as you find out at the end of the film, it does not come in time either.In the beginning of the film you see Derek killing several colored men who are breaking into his vehicle in the middle of the night. Derek is arrested and forced to serve time in prison. There he quickly finds others that believe and follow the white supremacy beliefs. He believes this group can help protect him from the black and Hispanic prisoners. He later finds out that this group is actually "paying" a colored group to keep them safe and he decides he does not want anything to do with them. The white group feels betrayed by him and becomes even more furious when he begins chatting with a colored man. This man is Lamont, who Derek works in the laundry room with at the prison. The white group ends up raping Derek the shower room. This is a real turning point for Derek as he is shamed by his own kind. He realizes the white supremacy beliefs are not the way he wants to continue to live his life.Derek ends up leaving jail as a new man, with new beliefs, but in the same world as he left it. He sees his brother, Danny, following in his footsteps and treating the colored folks in town the same way he used to. Derek is finally able to change his brother's views after he shares all he experienced in prison. Unfortunately, it is too late as Danny is shot at the end of the movie by a colored man in a restroom.One film American History X reminds me of is Once Upon a Time in America. This film is similar in the fact that a ganger is forced to return to an old life he had years ago and deal with the issues he left behind. This is similar to what Derek went through upon his release from jail.A couple of film techniques stood out to me while viewing this film. The first was black and white vs. color. The film was shot in color with the exception of many scenes which flashed back to different times in Derek's life. All of the bad memories were done in black and white, but the one happy scene at the end remained in color. This one flashback in color was of Derek and Danny running on the beach playing as young boys. The use of black and white in this film makes all the bad memories on Derek's life stand out.The other notable technique used in this film was the use of symbols. The large swastika tattooed on Derek's chest was a mark of white supremacy. This was shown in many scenes throughout the movie when he wanted to show the world his position on racism. At the end of the film, after he has changed his views, you see him touching and looking at it like he wants to get rid of it.I thought American History X was a great movie. It tackled the hard issues of racism and hatred and showed how people can change their thoughts when they get to really know each other.

Review title: "American History X", Ton y Kaye out does himself with his portrayal of racism in Los Angeles CA . Told through the eyes of Derek and Daniel Vinyard
Review_body: "American History X", a 1998 film by Tony Kaye, starring Edward Norton as Derek Vineyard, Edward Furlong as Daniel Vineyard, and Beverly D'Angelo as Doris Vineyard. The story is about two brothers growing up in Los Angeles, CA. Their father was murdered by a black drug dealer while fighting a fire in a South Central LA neighborhood. This leads to the racist tone of the movie and to Dereks hatred.The main theme in the movie is racism and the effects that it has on different groups of people. This can be seen throughout many of the scenes in the movie, one scene in particular was in the beginning when we are introduced to Derek who is seen bashing a black man's face against the curb for trying to steal from his truck. Derek is subsequently sent to prison where he finds out that being a white neo-nazi supremacist is not everything he use to think it was. Upon entering prison Derek shows off his swastika tattoo hoping to gain support and protection from other inmates that thought the way he did. This however is not the way it worked out for him. When Derek is finally released from prison he is a changed man, he no longer wants to have all the hate that he has carried with him for years and he doesn't want his little brother Daniel to follow in his footsteps. Another scene were the theme can really be seen is when Doris has a Jewish friend over for dinner, Derek cannot stand the fact that his mother has a Jewish friend and verbally abuses him and then throws him out of his house.In relation to the theme, "Crash" is another movie that shows a lot of the same racist tendencies. Both movies are set in Los Angeles, CA and almost draw on the natural tensions that come from that area.One technique that was used throughout the movie that I thought added a lot to the movie was the interchanging from color to black and white. Although most of the movie was in color the flashbacks that were used to depict portions of Derek's younger days were shown in black and white. I felt this did a good job of displaying the tensions and extreme hatred that Derek had at that time in his life by showing it in black and white, it gave the scene a different feel than the rest of the movie. Symbolism was also used throughout the movie. Derek showed off his swastika tattoo in prison to show his beliefs and with the hopes of finding others like him. The swastika can also be seen at the white supremacist rally. There are flags hanging in the barn and in Cameron Alexander the leader of the D.O.C.'s office along with pictures of nazi Germany. The music that is playing at the rally also adds to the theme of the movie.

Review title: It dealt with many racial issues and conflicts.
Review_body: American History X has been by far one of the best movies I've ever viewed. It shows you the different conflicts about how people are dealing with racial issues and how this guy (Derek) didn't want his son to make the same mistakes as he did when he was younger. This movie is very surreal and helps you depict the different views of the issues going on in this movie. I think the most emotional part of this movie was the very end. I'm not going to ruin it but by the way the movie is told. It's like everything just builds itself up to that very last scene. Everything the characters experienced was sent to a halt and was given a true glimpse of the cruel reality we live in.

Life's greatest lessons don't often come in little convenient packages and this movie is one that will teach you one aspect of American Life you don't want to miss. We all know hate is bad, that society is full of angry factions blaming each other for whatever pain and suffering or the dwindling American dream that used to shine with glory. But times are different now. Maybe America wasn't meant to be the way it is now; maybe the framers of this nation had in mind a different vision of what a free land should've been. But, then again, if history has taught us one thing, it is that we can not change history. We can change our destiny. We can change the present if we set our minds to it. But we gotta act. This movie doesn't merely teach us that hate is bad, the more important lesson is that, to make a difference in the world, we have to use our words and actions.

Review title: This is one of the best movies ever made.

In short this is an awesome movie, I mean, seriously, if you haven't seen this movie go rent it right now, leave right now don't even close this window, just go. Edward Norton's acting is dynamite. A lot would be learned and some possible changes could occur. Ed Norton gave an award winning performance. I try to find things wrong with movies of this type. I have seen this movie at least 20 times and to be honest I cant find a single flaw. Great film!!
