Review_body: Air tight 2 hour runtime which wastes little dialogue. Extremely dramatic scenes that all have a part in gripping ending. An important story told in an amazing story. You will not regret watching this movie at all and it well deserves its place among the greatest movies of all time.

Review title: This movie is an absolute masterpiece and should not be considered violent rubbish.
Review_body: This movie was and still is an absolute masterpiece, highlighting several issues still prominent in modern society. Edward Norton plays his role fantastically and brings life to his character, although this itself is somewhat spine chilling. The racial vilification which is shown in this movie is still relevant to todays society, although it may not be quite as brutal as shown. The violence, while some may consider it to be grotesque and disturbing is in context and as such cannot be considered to take away from the movie, just as it is in Stanley Kubrick's 'A Clockwork Orange'.Edward Furlong's performance completes a movie that will no doubt never be lost to the ages, while Ethan Suplee gives comic relief and still adds to the depth of the story with the portrayal of his character.While there is indeed a indeed an amount of violence in this film, it can only be considered to be in context and appropriate to the story. This film is a masterpiece, full of feeling and brutality that still occurs in places both in America. It can only be considered to be one of the all time great films, to write it off as mindless, violent rubbish is absolute sacrelidge. 10/10

Review title: A character extremely well constructed and a powerful and much need message against Neo-Nazism compensate for some of the story minor flaws
Review_body: This movie has a good story, worth being told, well structured, believable. But the story is not what makes this a great movie.What won the movie for me was Edward Norton's character Derek Vinyard. This movie could very easily made the mistake of showing him not as a character, but as a personification of mindless rage and hate, and even though the movie sometimes go out of his way to make it clear that his beliefs and attitudes are ultimately wrong (something very justifiable given the sensitive subject), they show us where all of this come from. They us what happened to a brilliant young man that made him into a monster, giving the character depth and making us feel the tragedy of his downfall into a skinhead.The movie in a somewhat subtle way shows us that, despite the facts of his life influencing in his choice, the responsibility for his mistakes is his alone. This is made by his sister's character, who in spite of living in the same environment turned out to be a decent human being. This contrast of a character who is brutal, ruthless, and destructive to everyone around him but is not simply a diabolic Disney villain makes this a good movie.Said that, the others characters work well, with highlights to Edward Furlong who plays very well Norton's brother.Furthermore, the movie works well with the violence, making the audiences cringe with it, feel the suffering of the victims and leaving no doubt that the skinheads crosses completely any moral standart and should in no way be praised or idolized. Making the violence feel this real is somewhat difficult in an age where we are so used to it that if a movie kills less than half a planet we barely even notice.The movie is not however perfect. Norton's time in prison takes a little from the movie's plausibility, since he would need to have the shortest of sights not to realize that his open confrontation of the other neo-Nazis would lead to his raping and almost to his death, and maybe his brother reform was a little rushed.Where the story fails, the character construction and the powerful message as well as it magnificent use of visual resources redempts it. All in all, a must see. 8,5/10

Edward Norton should have won in 1999. He was amazing, as Derek. In one Person: Rigid, crazy, and likable. Story was simple, however the evoked emotions was powerful. Though well-intentioned, turns out to be a simplistic and unconvincing look at a serious problem. This is, perhaps, one of the most difficult films there is there is to watch. Nobody gets out completely unscathed in this film. Not the white people, not the black people, not the correctional system (Norton's character kills two people and he gets out in three years), and certainly not the viewer. If there's the smallest seed of intolerance in the bowels of your soul, it will be shown to you, and it will not be pleasant. I'm a very tolerant person, and American History X shook me to my core. Thank you this movie for everybody in staff!

American History X is a movie about a boy who's brother has been in a Nazi-clan. The boy's name Daniel Vinyard and his brother is Dereck Vinyard. Daniel also becomes member of the clan. He sees his big brother as a kind of living example for his own lifestyle. Daniel had turned in a paper about "Mein Kampf" at school. The teacher ( who by the way is a dark-colored person ) does not accept it. He gives Daniel the order to write a paper about his brother's life. That's what the movie is about. In the movie you can see flashbacks about the life of Dereck and the actions he undertook with his clan. These actions are quite hard actions. Every not-white person was an evil person. But the strong thing about the movie is that not only Dereck and his clan are described as "bad" persons, also the "dark-colored" persons are evil. Both gangs are making rude actions and killing each other. The way the interaction between the two groups is described is very impressive. The movies characterizes in a good way too what wrong rascism can lead, from both sides. The end is also very impressive. I would say, watch the movie and your vision about rascism will change in a positive way. It is actually a non-necessary way of behaving. All people are equal and need to be threatened in that way. Greetings from Holland, Melchior Ensing

In the film American History X, Edward Norton plays Derek Vinyard, who after some influence by his father's words, and later anger from his father's murder by a black man, becomes a neo-Nazi and joins a local Nazi gang. Derek, who heavily influences his younger brother Danny, played by Edward Furlong, is informed one night by Danny that two black men are breaking into his truck outside. Derek then grabs his gun, runs outside, and proceeds to gun down the men. He then finishes off one of the would-be robbers by smashing his head on the curb. Soon after, he is arrested and convicted of manslaughter, and avoiding a murder charge because his younger brother refuses to testify against him.Derek undergoes a radical transformation in prison, as he realizes that much of the racism and hatred he has been taught to display by others is really only superficial, and really deep down inside, there is no real reason for such malice. This helps show the theme of the movie, racism and hatred are learned traits, not born into a person. After enduring a violent rape in prison, and befriending a fellow black inmate, Derek has a change of heart, and realizes the foolishness of his ways, and the ignorance of hate and racism. He realizes that the most important thing in life is family, and not hatred for people unlike him. After his release from prison, Derek forsakes his old friends including his old buddy Seth, played by Ethan Suplee, and even his girlfriend Stacy, played by Fairuza Balk, as he attempts to distance himself from the neo-Nazi movement. The movie draws to a conclusion as Danny comes face to face with a boy whom he had a confrontation with days before, in the bathroom of his school on the day he is scheduled to submit his paper, American History X. The boy pulls out a pistol and shoots Danny in the chest and kills him. Derek learns of his younger brother's murder and becomes terribly distraught. The film ends with Danny's words from his paper, quoting President Abraham Lincoln. This film helps the viewer understand that hatred and racism is not something that is born in someone, as Derek and Danny were not shown to display these characteristics as children, but learned to hate as they got older by influences around them. This is a similar situation to Walt Kowalski role, played by Clint Eastwood, in the movie Gran Torino, as he witnessed the exodus of white, middle-class people from his neighborhood, and the influx of minorities. American History X uses a reoccurring motif to make the viewer aware of the racist hatred bred in the boys by those around them. We constantly see Nazi propaganda, along with swastikas, etc. Also, the dialogue in the film and the use of constant racial slurs reinforced the hatred in these young men's hearts. It is clear that racism and hatred are not traits that are born in individuals, but rather created in the hearts of impressionable people by those wishing to spread their prejudiced views to others. The theme of this movie helps us understand that a good way to keep these feelings from those we love is to try not to influence, or let them be influenced by this kind of animosity.

American History X is one of the best films that I have seen in my lifetime. If I could, I would make it a mandatory viewing for every single individual. The moral lesson alone makes it a must see for everyone, especially those who are conflicted and caving to peer pressure; regardless of age. Throughout each of our lives we come to a cross roads at least once or twice where we have the opportunity to make a choice to let hatred consume us or to fight the urge for hatred to enter our hearts and our souls. This movie shows us how misdirected hatred can ruin lives, directly and indirectly. The film crew did a fantastic job collaborating to create a film that not only entertains, but one that makes the viewer think twice about the life they have lived and the impact they have had on the ones they love. I feel that all of the actors played their parts perfectly, but extra kudos goes to the core actors/characters: Edward Norton as Derek Vinyard and Edward Furlong as Danny Vinyard. These characters are played so well that you almost don't have a choice but to be pulled into the intensity of their lives. My favorite effects used in the movie, to my surprise, are the transitions from color images to black and white images. These transitions, in addition to the random and perfectly placed slow motion effects, enhance the emotional aspect of the film. As the story bounces around from present day/post incarceration and past/pre incarceration, it is easy to keep up with the storyline with the transition from color to black and white. I was surprised that I would like this aspect of the film, since I am not normally a big fan of black and white footage. The black and white images help the viewer to focus more on the emotions that need to be felt by the characters and the setting. On the surface, the film is about a reformed neo-nazi skinhead who, after being released from prison, tries to reverse the destruction he has created within his family – only to realize he is too late. Below the surface; however, is a much needed lesson that hatred of any kind will only destroy you and the people close to you. Regardless of what you believe when you allow anger to consume you, there is no good found in hatred. If you are looking for a fluffy film, this is definitely not the film for you. If you are looking to learn a much needed lesson about our culture and the world we live in, this is a must see.

Review title: I was reminded of the sheer power of this movie by watching it years later with my teenager.
Review_body: I originally watched this movie so many years ago and was floored by it. I had forgotten how many emotions it wrangles out of you that you may not even ever suspect. It was an eye opening movie for me as a younger person and when I found out my 19 year old boy hadn't seen it, I pulled out my DVD of it and said, "That's what we're doing tonight." He at first had no interest in it after checking out the synopsis on the case and I almost had to force him to watch it with me. However, as I began to get immersed in this movie that I had forgotten its powers, it got quiet and I never heard another word from him. At the end of the movie, I was sniffling and I look over and he is sitting on the edge of the couch with tears, unspilled, but sitting in his eyes, mouth open, slack-jawed, and still staring at the blank screen. It was definitely a defining period in his young adulthood and a moment for me that helped define our relationship and that I'll always cherish. It's a classic that even now sometimes I talk to people who haven't seen it, and I recommend it. I'm glad I bought the DVD so long ago. It had the same reaction for me as it did the first time years ago.I don't want to let out spoilers and it's so hard with this movie. So that's why I haven't gone into detail. But if you want to see real, emotional, life changing in certain situations, movies that make you question things and/or really force you to put yourself into someone else's shoes whether you want to or not, watch this movie.

-Danny Vinyard:"I'm sorry, Derek. I'm sorry that happened to you." -Derek Vinyard:"I'm not. I'm lucky. I feel lucky because it's wrong, Danny. It's wrong and it was eating me up, it was going to kill me. And I kept asking myself all the time, how did I buy into this sht? It was because I was pissd off, and nothing I ever did ever took that feeling away. I killed two guys, Danny, I killed them. And it didn't make me feel any different. It just got me more lost and I'm tired of being pissd off, Danny. I'm just tired of it." -Danny Vinyard: Hate is baggage. Life's too short to be pissd off all the time. It's just not worth it.Masterpiece!

American History X intentionally mixes up concepts to cause confusion to viewers. It relates crimes motivated by racism to conservative ideas in order to cause the viewer to mistakenly associate racism to conservatism.For example, in the scene with the discussion at the dinner table, Derek delivers many TRUE facts. For example, he says that the act of someone finding an excuse to loot a store is nothing but disrespect for law and community, and not a morally fair act (supposedly legitimated by a situation of economical difficulty, or any other reason), meaning that nothing justifies robbing someone. Right after saying this, the discussion goes to a racist bias (where Derek is obviously wrong). And right after this, Derek's sister gives Marxist propaganda on how crime is caused by 'social inequalities' (and is therefore justifiable), and not a matter of moral values. That is saying it is OK to rob someone if they are richer than you. Derek than argues (correctly) that this opinion of hers is just like taking one thing (robbery, for example) and calling it something else (redistribution, for example, or, to quote Derek, it's like saying "It's not crime, it's poverty"), with the intent to alleviate the responsibility of the one who commits it. That's exactly what Marxism does.This twisting of concepts happen in other passages of the film, where the speeches and dialogues intertwine racist and conservative ideas. For example, in the scene where Derek fairly criticizes welfare (which is basically looting tax-payers to give privileges to others) and right away he says something racist.The director's intent is clear: to unfairly associate racism to conservatism using a Nazi character to place conservative and racist ideas side by side, thus leading the naive viewer to wrongly believe these ideas are one and the same.

Possibly one of the worst movies I've ever seen. It reeks from start to finish, which is all the more painful because it was supposed to be good. Edward Norton sounds and looks more like the president of the Yale Republican Club than a white supremacist skinhead - the movies truly fatal flaw considering he's the linchpin of the whole thing. Elliot Gould as a woolly, ineffectual liberal is a stereotype, one of many in the cast.More troubling than the acting, though, is the direction, which could charitably be called confused. How else to explain why we end up rooting for the skinheads to beat the black guys in a basketball game to determine who will stay off the public courts of Venice for good. How else to explain that the skinheads actually win? On the Venice courts, where the level of play is so high that Ron Shelton actually set his own movie there ("White Men Can't Jump")? This scene is symbolic of how completely out of touch this movie is, how it ignores basic realities to construct its own while purporting to tell the truth, and how confused its storytelling and direction are. If racism is so bad, why are the majority of the black characters so unlikable, and why do the white supremacist characters seem so much more sympathetic and their actions so much more understandable? These concerns would be mere quibbles if the movie didn't claim to be so much more than it actually is. It fails to convey its message, and it fails artistically. Everything about it just sucks.

Review title: A movie with dozens of feelings.
Review_body: The fact that i haven't watched this movie before is painful. But thanks to my brother, i finally had the chance to watch it.One afternoon after school i lied down in front of the TV and watched it. I've watched the movie without any idea of the subject. The title of it had put up a ''Indian vs White Men'' kind of a thing in my mind. But it was much more different. I just hope that the simple minded humans won't see the reason of Edward Norton's character's change in the movie as rape. That laundry has changed him. Between all those white sheets there was a black sheet, and the blinding light of the white sheets has caused him to see peace in the black sheet. In the movie, it is perfectly represented that human mind is something else than just a follower of a path. My brother has a saying: ''Never hate the change, for the change is the very reason men was created.'' A man who can change is greater than the others.And man, what an ending! I never knew that i was such an emotional person. When i looked at the mirror after the credits, i had no difference than a tomato.Such a powerful movie. This movie has taught me hatred. It taught me passion. It taught me that the very things i defend might be wrong. It taught me not to be afraid of change. And most importantly, it showed me how life works.

I'm commenting only to add to gingerkris' comments with which I find no fault. I've seen many movies which include graphic violence in them, but I can think of none which have had the impact of a particular scene in this one.It's simply, horrifyingly, believable - the acting, direction, writing all contribute by joining to achieve that "suspension of disbelief" so often sought and so rarely achieved -you want to check the curtains, because it may just be outside, because these people may just be your neighbours.Clearly Norton's best performance so far, but if you remember it's a performance after the first few scenes, you're just not watching the movie.To amplify gk's closing comment (should be on every high school curriculum), as soon as my children are old enough to understand it and not be hurt by it, I'll be showing them this film so that they know what fascism means.

The movie was written by McKenna (presumably Gentile), and put out by New Line (Jewish owned). It would have been interesting to be a fly on the wall at the production meetings as they tried to balance the need to make an interesting movie (letting a Nazi make his case) against the need for Semitical Correctness.... I truly wonder where the writer's opinions lie. The indications are that he has a good deal more sympathy for the skins' case than the Jews' because the former is strongly drawn, while the latter is barely sketched.The guts of the movie are the speeches by Derek. Of these speeches, the best is his dinner-table destruction of the Jewish cant put out by the Elliot Gould character courting his mother in which he demolishes the Jew's inevitable excuse explanations of poverty and racism for Rodney King and the L.A. riots. Edward Norton is a fine actor, and is quite persuasive as a strong and principled skinhead. He is much less plausible as a post-prison reformed soul, but that is a script problem. We are supposed to believe that the principles he stated and defended at the risk of his life have been changed because he encountered a funny Black man and some corrupt White racists in prison. This failure of characterization was probably made necessary by the dictates of Semitical Correctness at New Line. I'm sure McKenna realizes that Derek would be nothing but entrenched in his beliefs by a stint in prison.In fact, at no point are the racist beliefs of the main characters Derek and younger brother Daniel challenged. By challenged, I mean shown to be logically or evidentially impaired. Instead, they are attacked modern-style, by fem-think. We see kicked-to-the-curb Gould saying "I'm sorry" to Derek's mother, his tragic gaze suggesting his horror at a son so far gone. Review title: Best of the ninety's liberal or not!
Review_body: American History X is about brothers Derek (played by Edward Norton) and Daniel Vinyard (played by Edward Furlong) whose father was a fireman responding to a fire. When reviving to the scene he gets shot by gang members.This leads to hatred against (mostly immigrants)foreigners from Derek and, being the eldest of the sons, he makes Daniel and the rest of his family grow up in a white supremacy surrounding. This will be shown in the movie many times, for example by hatred against a Jewish teacher who is trying to date his mother. Even though Daniel seems to be OK with the white supremacy surroundings, it's shown that he is more into having friends than being an outcast from his social surroundings. One day black gang members loose a basketball game against Derek's white gang. The looser would not show themselves ever again on the basketball court. This leads to retaliation and some of the black gang members are trying to steal the boy's deceased father's truck in the middle of the night. Daniel sees it and tells to Derek about it. Derek grabs his gun and kills two gang members in a brutal way. Derek is sentenced to prison for three years. Derek has a hard time fitting in to any group in prison and slowly becomes friend of another inmate who is black. This and many other factors make Derek finding him self in an ideological crisis. When he returns from prison reformed, his younger brother Daniel Vinyard who idolizes him is on the brink of becoming a Neo Nazi himself.Edward Norton and Edward Furlong do a breathtaking performance and you can really feel their repressed feelings and brotherly love for each other. Edward Norton transforms from a hateful Neo-Nazi to an intelligent normal man and does it in a realistic way. Edward Norton shows really good how he is trying to live up to Derek and feeling ashamed about it at the same time.Other actors like Beverly D'Angelo playing their mother are really good, too. She is being in a living hell after his husband's death and seeing her sons becoming racist. There are lots of smaller parts like Ethan Suplee's role as Seth Ryan, a dumb Derek idolizing, over weight racist, which makes the story just stronger. The movie is really violent in some parts but it is almost a must to keep the feeling so strong.Tony Kaye does an amazing job directing and timing every shot so that you don't get confused on flashbacks and what is happening at the moment. The movie reminds the viewer that we live in a world of chain reactions that can be transformed into hate and love. The film itself is a sincere and yet unrelentingly harsh look at race hatred in our modern society.The colour of the people is just what we see but as a human being we are all the same. Colour of the people is just what we see but as a human being we are all the same.Still, there are some problems. For example Dr. Sweeny (a black teacher) assigns Danny, the younger brother, to write an essay on his family history and his older brother's impact on his life. The paper is a part of what Sweeny calls "American History X." The film leads us to believe, then, that the movie a story about Danny. But it isn't. It's Derek's story. I think that it was an unnecessary for Daniel to begin the story or it could have been done better.Even though the movie is probably one of the best movies of the ninety's and leaves no one cold.

I have watched American History X three times now, and the reaction and feeling I get after watching it is always the same: stunned. Tony Kaye, who directed the movie, plunged us into the troubled and dangerous life of Venice Beach, California, torn apart by the different gangs fighting for their space. Edward Norton and Edward Furlong star in the film, and leave us both tongue-tied at the end of this amazing drama.The movie tells the story of two brothers involved in a Neo-Nazi movement, after the death of their father killed by a black drug dealer. The older brother, DerekVinyard (Edward Norton), is sentenced to 3 years of prison for manslaughter, and comes back from it with his beliefs entirely changed. The people he met and the things he saw and endured during this time made him realize the true and important things in life. He will then try to open his brother's (Edward Furlon) eyes to stop him from becoming what he used to be.One of the big paradoxes of this movie is the character of Derek. As much as we may have hated him at the beginning from all his racist thoughts, acts and violence against stranger but even his family, we cannot help but forgive his mistakes when he comes around at the end and try to make up for what he has done. Indeed, the intelligence of the character serving an awful purpose at the beginning comes eventually to his rescue and to the rescue of his family. This evolution is the greatest thing to witness and gives us an inexplicable joy. This is such a success thanks to the talent of Edward Norton, able to embody and incarnate really both sides of this character so well.Tony Kaye decided to build the movie based on flashback from the time the father was still alive, to make us understand how racism developed, rooted and almost destroyed this family. All the scenes from the past are in black and white, as if the director wanted to give us a hint on the end of the movie,saying "this time is over, things have changed now".Overall, the movie is captivating and surprising mostly because it does not have the same approach as most racism criticizing movies. It is not a judgmental view of racism here, even though it is still described as horrendous and unacceptable. Indeed, the director chose to show us more how can racism be accepted and defended in the context in which the family is living and how one's judgment can be obscured by the common vision you have to share when part of a group or gang like they are.Final word, this film is to be seen absolutely, but brace yourself, you are going to be startled and even shocked sometimes; it is part of the charm of American History X.

I am full aware that this movie is shown in high schools all over the world with the message of Tony Kaye still living on. This movie needs to be seen by everyone who may and if you show it to someone who has never seen it, it will surely not disappoint. It makes you contemplate the power of ignorance, the power of brotherhood, and the immense power of love towards a family. What is also interesting about the movie is that it is bringing up something that is still relevant today. White extremists are thought of as a minor group in any community but that doesn't change the fact that they still exist. In Sweden for example, fascists and white power-based parties are growing like never before since ww2 and so is political violence. It is still going on and that is why this movie is so important to watch and understand the morale before the violence.

Review title: A film that shows a life ruled by violence and racism until something tragic happens

The title refers to an assignment Danny has to write after the school principle, who was a black man, is outraged by Danny's history paper about Nazism, so he gives him the task to write about skin-heads for a special class named 'American History X'. An impressive movie, from all the things Derek has to face in prison, to the way he tries to change Danny, his younger brother, showing him that the path he has chosen is not right. Edward Norton's acting is beyond perfect, this has to be one of his greatest roles, Edward Furlong played very well, this movie would not be the same without them. Review title: spoiler alert. American can learn from this movie.
Review_body: A former skin head in L.A recently released from prison and now reformed, attempts to change his ways and correct his past battles, to better his brother that is following down the same dark path he had been down.The theme of American History X is struggle to change. Derek from the opening scene is almost looked at as a Christ like figure when the cops arrive they ask him to drop the weapon and turn around. The camera angle is upward and it goes slow motion. This scene makes him appear like a superhuman or God like figure especially when he puts his arms out like he is on a cross. Derek's tattoos are very noticeable in this scene you see the D.O.C tattoo which normally means department of corrections. But if you really think of it as a struggle to change to help his brother Danny than you might say it could stand for die on cross like God did.After the opening scene the story is told from Danny's point of view. Their father was a fire fighter that had been shot while on duty trying to put out a fire at a possible drug house. Their father seemed to plant a racist seed in Derek and Danny's brain at breakfast one morning when Derek had brought up about his teacher having them read a book about affirmative action. From their on he flashed back to the coming of power of his brother in the DOC. Everyone in the DOC seemed to look up to his brother as a leader. On the basketball courts the DOC play an all-black basketball team for the rights to stay on the courts. Derek ends up slam dunking a basketball to win the game he then hangs on the rim. This is shot in slow motion once again peering up at him hanging showing him as a power figure once again. While in prison Derek starts to become friends with a black man Lamont. They become friends while working in the laundry room at the prison. While Derek is locked up Danny starts to get into the DOC heavily and following after Cameron. Dr. Bob Sweeney was a teacher of Derek's in high school, and is now Danny's teacher. He ends up helping to get Derek out of prison early after he had been raped by other White Supremacist for becoming friends with black people in prison. Dr. Bob Sweeney wants Derek to help get Danny back on the straight and narrow. Once out Derek breaks ties with the DOC and starts to get Danny turned around. Everything seems to be looking up for Danny, Derek and their mother until the closing scene of the movie Danny has had a run in with a black student from his school in which this time the other student is finally going to get the last word. American History X in my opinion is very similar to Menace to Society in the way that the characters end up being fairly innocent in the start of the movie turn for the worst and start to make a turnaround for the better again and in both movies end up dying.Like I have pointed out I think the slow motion scenes along with the angle are two techniques to help show the theme of this movie. Everyone seems to look up to Derek and the slow motion throughout the different scenes adds to his power and authoritativeness of his character in this movie, by looking at him at an upward appearance along with panning over/ at him and his muscular physique in slow motion to make sure he is given attention."No one is born hating another person because of the color of his skin, or his background, or his religion. People must learn to hate, and if they can learn to hate, they can be taught to love, for love comes more naturally to the human heart than its opposite." -Nelson Mandela

Review title: A touch over-dramatic but otherwise a perfect film
Review_body: Yes, I agree, the slow-motion portions are there to make the scenes more dramatic than they need to be. Yes, the black and white for the flashbacks was unnecessary, but overall, this film has done for racism what Homeroom and Elephant did for school shootings.There is no explanation why Derek becomes a neo-nazi, yes his father was probably a part of it, as well as just being young and influenced by Cameron. It could also be attributed to his surroundings, the way he grew up, but there is no clear answer and that is what makes it so powerful. The fact that you don't have to be poor, you don't have to grow up in terrible surroundings, or have your parents influence you, to hate people that much.Edward Norton's performance was brilliant, his tone and body language was spot-on, although whenever he cried I was reminded that it was an actor playing a part and not Derek Vineyard. Edward Furlong may have been miscast but he still pulled Danny off very well, the voice-overs being perfectly apathetic.The cinematography was beautiful, the arrest scene when there was an American flag in the background behind Danny while the policeman was covering Derek's swastika, and the end scene was an amazing reminder of Lester in American Beauty. Red on white will always be the most powerful colors in my mind.Overall, I loved this film, not because it was "edgy" but because it, overall was better than 99% of the films I have seen and it left me shaking and in tears at the end, that is what I call a powerful film.

I have seen American History X several times and now own the DVD. This is a superb film, with focus on Edward Norton's character, "Derek Vineyard." Derek is a neo-Nazi growing up in Venice Beach, CA. The film is very moving and a realistic account of race relations in Southern California, and also of the inner workings of prison life. The ending of the film was a bit sad, and was probably the weakest part of the film, in my opinion. The film moves along superbly, however, after Derek is released from Prison, he is a changed person, and in my opinion, I'm not so sure he would have done a complete 180 like that, however, it makes sense for the films sake. All in all, this is very watchable. Certainly a rated R movie, very graphic and strong language.

"American History X" is a poignant story of family, redemption and retribution. It revolves around the life of Derek Vinyard, a Neo- Nazi who, after doing three years of prison and self-reflection, changes his ways, and when he is released from prison, tries to do the same for his younger brother; Danny Vinyard. Edward Norton does a fantastic job of portraying Derek, both before and after his transformation from his skinhead lifestyle. Norton accurately displays the opinions and thoughts of his character, without making him come across as your typical neo-nazi; Derek is an angry and frustrated man who blames blacks for his father's murder - yet he is intelligent and has his own opinions and thoughts regarding modern society; he is not narrow-minded, despite his strongly racist mindset. After his trasformation, Norton still plays Derek in a practically flaw- less manner, portraying him as the older brother filled with regret and remorse, but also someone who has not let this get the better of him. He portrays him as someone who now has responsibilities in his life, and also someone who is determined to turn both his and Danny's life ar- ound.Edward Norton is not the only actor in this film who does an outstanding job of portraying their character. Edward Furlong plays Danny, Derek's younger, confused brother. Furlong plays this character almost immaculately; he accurately portrays the frustration and rebellious nature that resides in this character. Danny was, for me, the most interesting character in the film; although I have no doubt others will disagree entirely. However, Danny is a high school student who has spent his whole life looking up to his brother Derek, idolizing him throughout his childhood and young adulthood, meaning that Dereks actions have reflected heavily onto his younger brother. In one scene, Derek has a dispute with his family about Derek's views. Danny rarely speaks in this act, but when he does, he is defending his brohter. The film is visually powerful. When the film is going through a flashback, the screen is changed to black and white, which helps to add to the overall dark tone of the film. One of the most notable aspects of the film are the prison scenes; During his jail time, Derek's only real friends turn out to be those who he thought he hated the most; the blacks. Derek befriends a black man named Lamont (played by Guy Torry) , who is essentially the biggest reason for Derek's transformation; He teaches Derek that, basically, not all black people are bad. When they first meet, Lamont knows that Derek is a skinhead; he knows that Derek most probably resents him just because of his skin colour. Despite this, Lamont still shows respect for Derek, showing him the ropes and being his only real friend in the prison. Derek's other black associate is a man named Sweeney, who is Danny's high school teacher. During the course of the film, Sweeney and Derek become closer friends, mainly through Danny. But here is the most important part: when Derek is assaulted in jail, Sweeney is literally the only one who is there for him. Lamont and Sweeney are possibly the two most important characters in the entire story; they prove to Derek that even whites can be bad, and that even blacks can be good. Without these two characters, when Derek left jail he probably would've just gone straight back to his old ways.In conclusion, "American History X" is a film that is not afraid to deal with common issues in American society head on. The film does not hold back, and hits the audience with cold, hard truth combined with it's gritty realism that leaves viewers in magnificent awe. AHX has one message, and it delivers it beautfully; and it is that if you follow the path of hatred, sooner or later you will pay the price.

This Movie gonna make me happy every time i watch it. The scariest and most convincing scenes are the ones in which we see the skinheads bonding. They're led by Derek's brilliant speech-making and filled by drugs, beer, tattoos, heavy metal and the need all insecure people feel to belong to a movement greater than themselves. It is assumed in their world (the beaches and playgrounds of the Venice area of L.A.) that all races stick together and are at undeclared war with all others. What we get, finally, is a series of well-drawn sketches and powerful scenes, in search of an organizing principle. The movie needs sweep where it only has plot. And Norton, effective as he is, comes across more as a bright kid with bad ideas than as a racist burning with hate. (I am reminded of Tim Roth's truly satanic skinhead in "Made in Britain," a 1982 film by Alan Clarke.) Kaye wanted to have his name removed as the film's director, arguing that the film needed more work and that Norton re-edited some sequences. We will probably never know the truth behind the controversy. My guess is that the post-production repairs were inspired by a screenplay that attempted to cover too much ground in too little time and yet hastens to a conventional conclusion.Still, I must be clear: This is a good and powerful film. If I am dissatisfied, it is because it contains the promise of being more than it is.

Review title: Does anyone think this movie has aged well?
Review_body: I had heard nothing but good things about this movie, but after watching it last night I can definitely say I was severely disappointed. The director (Tony Kaye) distanced himself from the final cut, so I'm not sure how much of the blame I can put on him versus Norton and New Line Cinema.The acting was stiff (I believe Norton miraculously won an award for his dry eyed performance), the dialogue was clunky, the cinematography resembles the work of an amateur film student, and the characters are written horribly.Kaye has made other movies which seem to be notorious for staying in the middle of issues and presenting both sides equally. This movie seems to lean heavily towards the Neo-Nazis by explaining their motives in depth and presenting most of the black characters as heartless stereotypical gangsters. The few exceptions to this are two characters who seemingly only exist to better the racists as if it's their job.Overall, I'm giving it a 3 because it somewhat tries to send a good message while still being confusingly sympathetic towards one side of a double edged sword (at best)

I honestly don't think I have ever seen a better movie than American History X in my entire life! I may only be 14, but I have seen a lot of movies. I am an avid fan of them, and this one just takes the cake. Edward Norton is just unbelievable. He is the most talented actor I've ever laid eyes on. His performance in the movie is phenomenal. He delves so deep into his character that he can convince the whole audience easily of his neo-nazi role. The look on his face as he walks back from killing one man in the first seen is purely horrifying. The entire move was dramatic, intriguing, and powerful. It really is moving and emotional as well as scary. It is so true to life, and provides the viewer with such insight into the life and events that create a monster such as Derek Vinyard. It answers many questions I have long awaited an answer to such as what could possibly make someone act as Derek did in this movie, yet left open-ended many others that people such as myself may have. Almost every single scene in the movie was extremely captivating. I can't even go on to say more about the acting, other than if Edward Norton does not win best actor this year, I will go absolutely nuts. It's bad enough he lost it to Cuba Gooding Jr. when he was in Primal Fear, which was yet another incredible performance by him. Edward Furlong, the little kid from T2 is astounding as the confused brother of Derek. I was stunned walking out of the theater after seeing American History X, and I don't think I will ever have the benefit of seeing another movie as good as this one as long as I live. I recommend anyone with a good tolerance for violent and graphic depictions go see this movie. I am bewildered as to why director Tony Kaye would ever want out of this success. If I were to rate this movie, as I often do for others in reviewing them for school, I would give it an A+ with all of my heart.

Recently, I saw American History X again, because I had some work to do about it and because I was very pleased with it the first time I saw it. The truth is, you can't get bored by watching it.Without intention to challenge the fact that it is a great movie, something that can disappoint people is that some scenes are probably far too romantic and easily predictable. Theoretically, the movie claims to point the finger at racism ; it attempts to show us the conversion of the protagonist to the path of righteousness. Of course it is a noble goal, but some parts of the story look naive or even childish (Derek's conversion seems absolutely not rational for example), despite the fact that others are actually maybe not enough romantic because they tend to show us a reality which looks far away from us : hardcore violence and racism.In this review I would like to examine the inner morality of the movie. American History X has often been accused of a "morally dangerous cinematic seduction". What the critics mean is that the film would manipulate the viewer through "glamorizing an immoral and hate- filled neo-nazi protagonist", instead of denouncing racism. All this by using cinematic effects and techniques. However, I don't think that this argument is relevant. The film, as a matter of fact, takes place in an historical context and shows Derek's life and what happens to him. Of course you will understand why he's angry, how he became who he is. Nonetheless, it doesn't mean that it justifies his ideology : it is the way that the film uses to introduce us the white supremacy groups world and the conflicts of those times. The techniques employed may allow for many viewers a degree of sympathy towards Derek, but that is actually for me an interesting point of the movie. What I mean is that we can see the story within that contested groups and this is the master card of American History X.

Review title: Great film, regardless of any bias one may have.
Review_body: While not perfect of course, this movie does do a wonderful job of exposing what racism and hate can do to a person or what effects they have on families. The main character, Danny, finds himself following the same White Supremacist cult that his older brother Derek had followed, which ultimately led to his arrest early in the film. Throughout the rest of the film, both Derek and Danny go through the same character arc - from racism to tolerance. There are many flashback, as well as present scenes in the movie that are very difficult to watch, but this is how director Tony Kaye constructs the picture of racism in households in America and the effects it has. The only complaint I have about this movie is the ending, I believe it is too ambiguous for the movie; but then again, it may be best that way.

It is rare that a film carries such weight and violence without feeling bloated, yet the grittiness of the film lends itself to heavy subject matter. I can still hear those teeth chattering against the concrete when I think of monotone intro that sets the tone. This movie could have been made today and it would have been great, but the 90s quality and feel inherent in the picture sets it apart. There are so many moments through the story that could be seen as shock value, but it always seems right. It's a perfectly gritty film about a very dark undercurrent that runs through America and likely always will to some extent. It's raw, honest, and ultimately heartbreaking as humans are terribly, terribly flawed, and that makes for compelling story lines.

American History X American History X is a magnificent movie and I would definitely rate it as one of the greatest movies dealing with the extremely sensitive topic of racism. Directed by debutant Tony Kaye, it examines and digs deep into the roots of prejudice.It is the story of a teenager Derek Vinyard, played by Edward Norton, who descents into Neo-Nazism after the death of his father. He is sent into the jail for killing two black people. In there, he has some life changing experiences which force him to retrospect the choices that he made. Meanwhile, his younger brother, Danny Vinyard is looking to follow his footsteps by joining the gang of neo-Nazists skinheads.Norton plays the role so persuasively and convincingly that it is easy to see how people get caught up in all this hatred.He was also runner up for the Oscars in the Best actor category for the same. Edward Furlong, who plays the role of Danny Vinyard along with the rest of the cast do their job pretty decently.All in all, the movie is filled with violence, racist spouting and tons of profanity and yet is an extremely compelling movie right from the beginning to the end. It is an unrelenting movie and seldom makes an easy choice. Finally, this movie gives a very simple take home message - " Hate is a baggage. Life is too short to be angry off all the time. It's just not worth it. "

After that treatment he will learn not to be an evil white racist Nazi anymore, but his massive past racial sins will continue to hunt him anyway and in the end his beloved brother will have to die because of the older brother's hate and evil white Nazi racism.Only a clearly paranoid director with racial hang-ups could have come up with this script.

This movie is directly related to Spike Lee's "Malcolm X," where both characters experience the metamorphoses of: 1) Self-hate 2) Extreme hate of viewed opponents and oppressors 3) A balance and realizationI've learned a lot from these two movies. They speak directly of the balance that exists everywhere, which is inevitable and everlasting. Balance always exists, but the process by which it is achieved can be drastic and violent sometimes. (Derek kills two black men; later, his brother is killed by a black teenager.) So, extremity can sometimes be the only way to go about solving things, but it ultimately needs to balanced out with logic. White supremacy in slavery leads to black supremacy in the civil rights movement, which leads to white supremacy immediately after. I used to think it was weak to be balanced in my viewpoints of the world. While it is okay to be angry and believe things are unfair, finding balance is the ultimate outcome. Well, either you find balance for yourself, or balance finds you, and sometimes it isn't the most pleasurable lesson.After birth comes death, and from death comes birth.

Review title: I love this film for all the right reasons!!

Just rewatched it in 2017 and still enjoyed it as much as when I originally watched it back in the 90's

Where should I begin? This movie is beyond borders. First of all is the portraying of two brothers and their path in finding identity. The oldest brother, Derek, finds home in the local nazi-gang and Danny is soon to follow. This is implied in a very nice way and as a viewer you never really question why.The second treasure in this movie is everything we learn about group-identity. After watching, you will understand so much better why people join the nazis. The whole movie is very thought-out by the writers and in my psychology-course we have analysed it in many ways. We have for example talked about why the mother doesn't argue against the boys behavior and how the nazi-group works as a "home".And then there is all the rest camerawork, acting...down to costume it's all absolutely great. The only reason why I don't give it a ten is that I sometimes think it's a little bit too violent. I understand why the writers have chosen to contain all the terror but why does it need to be so brutal and outspoken?

Review title: Amazing Acting, on an amazing story
Review_body: American History X is very well down, with amazing acting (as usual) on the part of Ed Norton, in particular. I was also particularly pleased with Avery Brooks' performance. Ed Norton excels in playing dynamic characters, and this performance is in-line with his acting in Fight Club and The People vs. Larry Flint -- his performance is an honest and believable portrayal of self-recognition and redemptionThe camera work and direction are well-designed and artistic. If there's one thing this movie lacks, however, the writing is not on the same par as the rest of the movie -- the overall screenplay makes a classic, but the individual lines fall flat and some of the mechanics used for exposition fall pretty flat.
Long story short:Great actors, great story, well played!!

Americam History X,is a very good movie. I saw it when it first came out in the theaters, and I was directly changed on some of my point of views, that I had before the movie. Edward Norton, which gained about 30 pounds of muscle for this movie was astonishingly, with his roll and how he played it. Edward Furlong also played a good role. Here is a review of the movie. The story follows an intelligent young man named Derek Vinyard (Edward Norton) and his decline into the world of disillusion and hate known as White Supremacy. Derek Vinyard (Edward Norton) buffed up to 190 pounds, with a shaved head, swastika tattoo, biker goatee and a feral, angry gaze, he is one scary image. Once a thoughtful and easy-going teen, he soon begins his change when his casually racist firefighter father is killed while trying to put out a fire in a black neighborhood. Falling under the wind of a neo-Nazi (Stacy Keach), Derek becomes a recruiting agent for local white kids. While the local movement grows, Derek gets deeper and deeper in, polluted more and more by hate. This all comes together when Derek kills two black gang members who tried to steal his truck. He is caught and sent to jail, where he is shown the error of his ways. The hard way. With the help of one of his former teachers (Avery Brooks), Derek begins to reform. However, it may be too little too late. While Derek was in prison, his younger brother Danny (Edward Furlong) is starting to head down the same path. Now, aside from trying to leave the world he created he has to save his little brother from it too. I had do to a movie review for my English class so I watched the movie again, and I was not nearly as pleased as the first time. The movie seemed kind of all fake and so played out. You knew what was going to happen next. So I guess if I was you I would only see it once, and I would definitely not buy the DVD unless you collect movies, because this would be a very good movie to add to your collection.

Review title: A Powerful, Eye Opening Story About Change
Review_body: When I first came across the movie American History X it was while I was looking through Edward Nortons films on his profile. Having seen Primal Fear and Fight Club just a few weeks prior to this I was intrigued to see what other roles he could take on. Furthermore, I was a huge fan of Edward Furlong in Terminator 2 and was happily surprised to see him on this cast list as between 1991 and 1998 when this was released, he did not have many major roles.The story is told through switching from present to past and the way it is done is simply outstanding. The flashback scenes are in black and white to firstly make it clear when the time period is and arguably also to show the darkness that was consuming Edward Nortons character when following the neo-nazi way of life that he did for so long. Edward Norton himself also adds to this effect and his performance makes it seem like he is playing two separate characters. His brother in the movie 'Danny' is played by Edward Furlong who gives a very gripping performance as we see his character change his ways completely in front of our eyes. The time period of only one day also adds the severity of this change and in a very powerful way shows the effect of influence that one person can have on another.For people that haven't seen this movie it is without a doubt one of the most powerful movies I have personally seen and one that I believe everyone should watch. Because of this, I have not given away many details of the movie and I believe that words cannot convey the true message that this 'masterpiece' conveys.10/10. Cinematic Brilliance

Review title: As much as i hate it, this story is the story of America.
Review_body: I watched this film when I was about fifteen years old. As an African American I wanted to watch this film for understanding. I got that and more. The story follows the life of a former Neo-Nazi sent to prison for a hate crime he had committed. While imprisoned his beliefs are transformed for a more positive outlook. He returns home only to find his little brother following in his footsteps. The main character, Derek, portrayed by Edward Norton was your typical white Supremist; full of hatred and stupidity. This is the type of movie that you love to hate. It was very well-acted I personally believed that the Academy Award belonged to Edward Norton for best actor. I hate however, that his little brother, Danny(played by Edward Furlong), was murdered by a black man. Just when it seemed like Derek had came around, he could have very easily been pushed back into the hatred he had once embraced, by the premature death of his brother. Easily put: what goes around comes around, and it sucks. The musical score to this film was awesome, the instrumental score really brought depth and meaning to certain turning points in the film. This movie really displayed the consequences of our beliefs and actions, whether good or bad.

This is a fantastic movie because no matter what side you're on in life, this movie shows them all, good and bad, right or wrong. I also agree with the point in the movie that proves that people can change for the better and straighten things out in their head to do the right things in life. Yes, things in our world have changed, some for the good, some for the bad, but just because you might not agree with some of it, doesn't mean you can play God and try to make things "your way" and this shows exactly what happens when you try. This movie talks about all walks of life and the struggles we all have in what beliefs are right and wrong. Yes this movie is brutal and violent, but also truthful to the past and unfortunately still sometimes the present. This movie is about race, but not only 1 race is singled out and fed to the dogs, they all are. So, go into this movie with an open mind and your mind will come out full.

Review title: A movie that will be remembered in history
Review_body: A psychologicaly stimulating movie straight from the shoot. The lessons and morals that this movie portrays in the underlying message is extremely profound. When we can learn to put our conditioned hate away and see people for who they truly are then we will finally see who we are to our core.

Well,i believe that's how one should make a movie...No doubt , this is the best film i watched last month and probably one of the best i've seen so far.Edward Norton's remarkable play,( as we are all already accustomed, since many know his Fight Club,25th Hour roles ), as well as the script and the direction make it a great movie which makes one seriously meditate upon the racial problems. It is just one of those movies , which , after you've seen them , make you feel you're a new man:trying to think and question the inertia of social behavior and the cruel attitude people have towards some of their somehow different peers, let's say of different race or religion. Trying to be myself more open , twice thinking of the facts i hear about and the real value of the man next to me - this is the effect this good film had upon me. The story is sad and it makes me hate the way people cause terrible losses with their selfish and ignorant attitude. The Soundtrack is very good. Enjoy it!

This movie has it all! The story builds up in a very original and strong, but subtle way and it is a good story. The whole story is believable, no unlikely plot twists, although there are some twists. The acting is great, especially Edward Norton. I was impressed!

American History X is the kind of movie which shivers your balls with freight,and you have no idea what is going on,and how these matters are dealt in a movie in such a public way.But it won't be soon before the dramatic,constrained part of the movie hit the screen and the transformation of the shaveheaded Edward Norton to the haired,transformed person.The movie deals with such a great complex ideology,yet Tony Kaye dealt it in a beautifull unravishing manner,that it becomes a masterpiece.The climax is topnotch,emotional scenes are well handled by Norton,the overall movie is completely attention-seeky.Watch it and get amazed of how a movie can expand a simple ideology into two hours of realism.

American History X also has one of the most shocking endings ever. But its ambiguity is what makes it more dreadful. It's an ending that can make you question the protagonist's fate, and that's more than horrifying!

Review title: My favorite movie of all time
Review_body: American History X is my all time favorite movie. Edward Norton was unbelievable in this! I first saw it when it came out many, many years ago. I actually watched it a few weeks ago. It's a classic. A must see. You have to understand that there are parts that will make you want to close your eyes. Just know, it is worth watching. Edward Norton is an incredible actor, actually they all are. It's a real movie, because sadly it is happening. Let's all put an end to Racism. I love everyone! People are beautiful, culture is beautiful.
